fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.bodyText: It was technically incorrect to say, as we did in an article, Winner takes all, page 10, G2, October 29, that Dawn Reed and Christopher Lillie, two former nursery nurses, won maximum damages against Newcastle city council. The damages were awarded against the authors (known as the review team) of the report that gave rise to the action. The council's defence of qualified privilege as the publisher of the report succeeded. However, the council is indemnifying the review team and it is the council therefore that is actually paying the damages. · An aircraft carrier is a warship but it is misleading to call it a battleship: Battleship rivals promise jobs (headline, page 29, October 30). A battleship is (or rather was) a battleship. · In our Sidelines column, page 8, G2, October 30, we asked, "... who is Fern Britten?" We do not know, but we know who Fern Britton is. · The Torrey (not Torre) Canyon was the oil tanker that ran aground in March 1967 (page 5, G2, yesterday). It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. Readers may contact the office of the readers' editor by telephoning 0845 451 9589 between 11am and 5pm Monday to Friday (all calls are charged at local rate). Mail to Readers' editor, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Fax 020-7239 9997. Email: reader@theguardian.com
